bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, January 8, 1940

div1.p: Hench provides information about the Founder's Day speakers. He plans to see Moran in March and suggests inviting him to the ceremony. Hench will visit and film Moran and Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, January 8, 1940
div1.p:
I am delighted that my preliminary suggestions appeal to you. I made
discreet inquiries, and Dr. Wilson, Emeritus Director of the Mayo Foundation,
knows of Dr. Henry K. Mohler, but does not know about his speaking ability. However,
my first assistant was one of his students at Jefferson, and just between you and me,
he gave me the following summary: he said that he was just another good doctor who
had played around with the right crowd, and had played medical politics with sufficient
success to earn this job as the Dean. He called him an average speaker, and said, “I
wouldn't pick him to entertain me, or any other crowd of people.” However, that is
neither here nor there, if you are inviting him for some ulterior motive regarding
the stolen picture. It all goes to show that one gets invited to do things not always
for the same reason:

If you decide on Dr. Sawyer, I would suggest that you try to get after him
pretty early. I understand that he travels all over North and South America, and
naturally you would want to date him up pretty long ahead of time.

I shall go ahead with my plans for the informal talk, thinking of you and
planning for your affair, but I will not be worried in the very slightest iota should
you decide to change your plans. I want to see Moran anyhow. He is in Havana, and
Mary and I will run over there from Florida when we go there in March. I hope to
ramble around the old site of the camp and will get some movies of Moran as he now
is and of the camp as it now looks, etc. Moran is the O'Hara of the Saturday Evening
Post story. I saw that story at once and have it in my files. I have many letters
from him. He is connected with the Sunoco Oil Co. but is getting along in years and
has a bad ulcer of the stomach. Would you want me to write to him about the possi-
bility of coming up for Founders' Day? Perhaps, if you are not in too much of a hurry,
it would be better for me to discuss it with him tangentially when I see him. He
doesn't seem to get to America very often, but it is quite possible that if I were
armed with a nice letter from you (not promising him much, but nevertheless inviting
him) that he would be glad to come.

I am delighted that you thought well of my suggestion to send you the
illustrated London News. I think you will enjoy it, and I have put in the subscription
for it. We had a very happy Christmas and New Years.
We are still looking forward to a visit from you at any time you can come.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
